Comment: How was he lawfully in this country, exactly? He had no legal status here of any kind. The only thing preventing him from being sent to El Salvador was a withholding order. He could’ve been deported to any other country that would take him.
Author: Szorja

Author: AstraVolans_21

Comment: He was lawfully in the country in the sense that his deportation to El Salvador was denied by an immigration judge. In order to proceed with any other deportation, he would have needed to be given notice, and an opportunity to refute it (e.g. appearing before another immigration judge). The fact of the matter is, his deportation to El Salvador was denied, and no other avenues were pursued, thus he was lawfully residing in the U.S. at the time of his capture. ICE cannot overrule the judiciary.
Author: check_your_bias7

Comment: Saying he was lawfully in the country is still a bit of a stretch. He was in immigration limbo via the withholding order. The judiciary was withholding him from being deported back to El Salvador. But he was still never granted asylum, no green card, nothing that would give him legal status to be here. And yes, obviously the withholding order was violated by deporting him, but he was not lawfully here.
Author: Szorja

Comment: I see what you mean. Perhaps a better way to phrase it would be 'it was unlawful to deport him to El Salvador'
Author: check_your_bias7
